And the case is such that, so in Rspec-Given you write things like given-then-when, or given-when-then, sorry, blocks, given this, then this, when that, et cetera. And so, thereâ€™s this bit of code in Rspec-Given thatâ€™s really neat. He has a failure object and it can run code in a context and catch any exception that comes with it. And then you can check for that, the matchers that check for have failed, they say, â€œIs it an Rspec-Given failure?â€ basically. But the cool thing is this exception object is wired up like BlankSlate where everything in it just re-raises the original exception. So, if you try to do anything with it, if you thought it was a number and then you try to add it to something, thatâ€™s going to call the plus method. And that wasnâ€™t counted on, so that itâ€™s going raise the original exception because it saved it. The context is still correct and points back to the right line numbers in your code and stuff. JOSH:Â  Letâ€™s get to the punchline of his style, which is that Jim said use do end if youâ€™re using the blockâ€¦ AVDI:Â  Side effects. JOSH:Â  Without caring about the return value. So, the way I look at it, if youâ€™re changing your curly braces to do end just because the block got biggerâ€¦ JAMES:Â  Right. AVDI:Â  If you look at the diff, the part of the diff thatâ€™s showing the change from curly braces to do end, thatâ€™s just noise. Itâ€™s distracting from the important thing, which is that the block got bigger. And itâ€™s very common for blocks to get bigger and smaller, to go from one line to multiline. JAMES:Â  Right, because the name of the iterator typically implies whether or not you care about the return value. AVDI:Â  Right. AVDI:Â  Sure, yeah. And this is one of the things he sent me in that email years ago, when I asked him about his insight into exceptions. And what he showed me was that convention for how he uses the fail and raise keywords in Ruby. A lot of people now might not even realize that there are two ways to raise an exception in Ruby, that you can use either raise or fail. Theyâ€™re both methods on kernel. They both do the exact same thing. Theyâ€™re basically just aliases for the same thing. And I think style these days has gone toward just using raise for everything. But what Jim showed me was that he uses the two different methods for two different things. So, most of the time, he uses fail. If he wants to indicate that there was a failure of any kind, he uses fail to signal the exception. But then in the rarer case where he rescues and exception and then decides to re-raise it, thatâ€™s where he uses raise. So, he uses raise strictly to signal an exception thatâ€™s being re-raised after being rescued. And I really like that style. Again, itâ€™s a way of using Rubyâ€™s multiple ways of doing things in a way that gives a signal to the reader. Itâ€™s a cue to the reader that says, â€œHey, pay attention here.â€ JOSH:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s actually I think a really subtle thing that is worth focusing on a little, is that Ruby gives you a lot of different options for how to do things. And you can just settle on one thing. Say okay, Iâ€™m always going to use collect instead of map. You could be Josh Susser and just say, â€œIâ€™m always using collect instead of map.â€ AVDI:Â  [Chuckles] And itâ€™s worth pointing out that back in the old days, some people settled on only using one kind of block, only using curly braces for instance. JOSH:Â  Right, right. But Jimâ€™s approach was, okay, the language gives us a couple of different ways of doing the same thing. And thatâ€™s more information that I can put in my code.
